block.p: Dr. Marya Gwadz and Nicholas Nathan Viorst were married yesterday by Dr. Khoren Arisian, a senior leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, at the Metropolitan Building, a converted factory that is now a space for social functions, in Long Island City, Queens.

The bride, 36, will be known as Marya Viorst Gwadz. She is a principal investigator for H.I.V. research studies at the Institute for Research on Youth at Risk in Manhattan. She graduated magna cum laude from the University of Rochester and received a master's degree and a Ph.D. in clinical psychology from New York University. She is the daughter of Carolyn Gwadz and Dr. Robert Gwadz, both of Bethesda, Md. The bride's father, a medical entomologist, is the assistant chief of the Laboratory of Parasitic Diseases at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases in Bethesda.

She graduated magna cum laude from the University of Rochester and received a master's degree and a Ph.D. in clinical psychology from New York University. She is the daughter of Carolyn Gwadz and Dr. Robert Gwadz, both of Bethesda, Md. The bride's father, a medical entomologist, is the assistant chief of the Laboratory of Parasitic Diseases at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases in Bethesda.

The bridegroom, 37, is the editorial director of Grand Central Press, a book development company in Manhattan. He graduated from Princeton University and received a master's degree in political science from the University of Chicago.

He is a son of Milton and Judith Viorst of Washington. His mother is the author of books for adults and children, including ''Necessary Losses'' (Simon & Schuster, 1986) and ''Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day'' (Atheneum, 1972). His father is a writer on the Middle East, whose most recent book is ''In the Shadow of the Prophet: The Struggle for the Soul of Islam'' (Anchor Books, 1998).
